This is a devastating loss for me, but also for our community. I am heartened that Sonny's legacy will continue to touch lives and enrich generations to come. My deepest sympathies to Gladys, Steve, and the Bass family. I join you in mourning and celebrating a truly great man.

So many will cherish every moment they had with Sonny, whether just a laugh, word of wisdom, bit of magic, or tiny toy he had at the ready to dazzle young or old. The mark he left on all he encountered was always bright, indelible, and made us feel good about ourselves.

Many know Sonny and his wonderful wife Gladys for their tremendous generosity to the University of Louisville and community organizations. And that would be enough. Their support facilitates countless good works and improves more lives than we can count. But it's just one part.

I am heartbroken by the loss of Sonny Bass. For as long as I can remember, Sonny has been a dear friend, first to my father and then to me. I have always been able to count on him for support, kindness, advice, and unbridled honesty.

@Chesschick01 @ReedCoverdale Nobody disagrees with that. He’s not saying that one can’t have an opinion on others’ behaviors. He constantly expressed such opinions. He’s talking about the wrongness of using force to impose one’s will on another.

@Chesschick01 @ReedCoverdale I don’t think you believe that saying someone should act responsibly is equivalent to a government mandate. Libertarians shouldn’t be scared of differing opinions. Opposing mandates goes hand in hand with using market forces like verbal disapproval of behavior.
@HoneyBadger5719 Trump was impeached.
@Chesschick01 @ReedCoverdale I’m not for the mandates, though. You’re going in circles.

@redleger @Chesschick01 @ReedCoverdale Then you’re either being disingenuous or have only a few tweets in mind out of thousands. If the latter, well, everyone agrees about some things from time to time, so that’s not unique to me. There are times at which Ron Paul and Swalwell agree, too.

@Chesschick01 @ReedCoverdale I can’t speak for what others have said, but libertarians aren’t against having opinions about other people’s behaviors. Liberty is about having opinions and telling people when you think they’re wrong. You and others tell me when you think I’m wrong all the time. That’s fine.

@Chesschick01 There are actual people dying from COVID-19. Lots of them. There are also people dying from government restrictions. No need to think any of it is “planned.” Why can’t it just be a virus plus the natural tendency of humans to move toward authoritarianism in times of crisis?
@David_J_Bosch There are more than two positions. The fact that certain people don’t like Trump doesn’t mean we need to embrace him or even tiptoe around him.

@Wildest_Ride @David_J_Bosch I’m refusing to compromise my beliefs. Period. I’m also confident that watering down my beliefs (e.g., to appeal just or mainly to Trump supporters) would attract a much narrower base.

@David_J_Bosch Imagine if our position had been not to genuinely criticize Obama (see my many, many tweets criticizing him) because we don’t want to alienate Obama voters. After all, there are countless Obama voters who support many libertarian principles and positions.

@David_J_Bosch No, it’s precisely because the sphere of potential allies is so big that we don’t need to kowtow to any one group. We can be libertarians. We don’t need to be nationalists or progressives. There are millions of Americans ready to be with us.

@David_J_Bosch I’ve been consistently and openly against lockdowns. I think the issue is you’re reading my tweets searching for a reason to be upset. Maybe it’s because I’ve refused to conform to the idea that just one group is the farm team for libertarians. We don’t need to narrow our appeal.

@David_J_Bosch That’s a strange take. There are people everywhere looking for an alternative. Some like Trump. Some like Obama. Some like Ron Paul. Some dislike each or all of them. We should speak truth about issues. The sphere of potential allies is much bigger than you seem to assume.
@David_J_Bosch @jakehsnider I’m speaking the truth. The fact that some libertarians can’t see the harm Trump does is a blind spot that undermines libertarianism.
@David_J_Bosch Personal responsibility is so anti-liberty, right?

@jakehsnider In fairness, a significant amount of irresponsible behavior stems from two things: (1) Donald Trump‘s reckless rhetoric and (2) protest of what many see as often arbitrary laws, combined with hypocrisy of government officials. I think more trust begets more responsible behavior.
@SGS_1988 Not through federal legislation.
You can be against government-mandated lockdowns and for individuals and businesses acting responsibly in a pandemic.

@heather4liberty Like any election, there are isolated incidents of fraud. No clear evidence of systematic wrongdoing to change the election’s outcome has been presented. They’ve lost in nearly every court. The president and his influential allies are perpetrating a scam for his personal benefit.
@ReedCoverdale @joerogan @TulsiGabbard I’d be happy to go on his podcast. Regular listener.
@anonresister That’s false. The Libertarian Party has nothing to do with Trump. We had our own presidential candidate. The people on the suits are not Libertarians.

@QuincyAdams97 Different levels of government handle different things in a federalist system. We divide powers to protect rights, so that everyone isn’t beholden to one person (like Donald Trump). A Libertarian can believe in everything you mentioned but at the appropriate level of government.
@jabby912 Libertarians have diverse views on abortion, and it is not a litmus test for being in the party.
@mietbee Some Libertarians support UBI as an alternative to the current welfare state. Join the party.
If you believe in individual liberty and the Rule of Law, the Constitution and federalism, justice and peace, honor and integrity, there is a home for you in the Libertarian Party.

I’m committed to working across the aisle to build support for these efforts because that is the most durable path forward for #ClimateAction and protecting my home state of Delaware, the nation’s lowest-lying state.

Countries are convening today to renew their climate commitments, and I’m hopeful because President-elect Biden will make addressing climate change a top priority. 

He has promised to rejoin the Paris Agreement and help lead us towards a more sustainable future.

But instead of joining our international partners in taking steps to reach net-zero emissions by 2050, President Trump spent the last four years rolling back environmental protections and abdicating U.S. leadership on what must be a global effort to combat climate change.

It was clear five years ago—and even clearer today—that without action, climate change will continue to cost our communities and economy in the form of more frequent and intense storms and wildfires, rising sea levels, and increased risk for dislocation and infectious disease.

I was one of the senators who attended the Paris climate talks in 2015, which brought the world together around the Paris Agreement—a bold consensus on #ClimateAction and our responsibility to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.
